title: How to Preserve Tomato Puree

steps.headline: Clean an ice cube tray.
steps.description: If your trays are dishwasher-safe, you can run them through a dishwasher on a hot cycle. If they’re not, or you don’t have a dishwasher, use warm soapy water.

steps.headline: Spoon the puree into an ice cube tray.
steps.description: Spooning in the puree will make sure that each cube has the same amount and prevent them from overflowing. Cooling the puree before putting it in the ice cube tray will make it freeze faster. Standard ice cube trays usually hold 2 tablespoons (1.0  fl oz) in each well. This lets you know how much is in each cube when you use it.

steps.headline: Cover the tray with cling wrap or a freezer bag.
steps.description: This will stop dust and crumbs from getting in the puree.

steps.headline: Freeze the tray of puree until it’s solid.
steps.description: This should take around 4 hours. The puree cubes should be able to keep their shape when you take them out of the tray.

steps.headline: Put frozen cubes in an airtight bag or container.
steps.description: Once the puree cubes have frozen, get an airtight container, freezer bag or Ziplock bag to store them in. Be sure to use plastic containers for freezing and not glass, as glass might crack. Make sure the container or bag is sealed tight before storing to stop moisture from building up inside, keeping your puree fresher for longer.

steps.headline: Store the cubes in the freezer until you need them.
steps.description: The puree cubes will keep for approximately 2 months. Label the bags or containers of cubes with the date before you store them. If you’re planning on freezing the puree for a long period of time, place them near the back of the freezer, away from the door. This will prevent thawing.

steps.headline: Sterilize the canning jars.
steps.description: You can sterilize the jars by placing them in boiling water for 10 minutes, or by running them through a hot cycle in a dishwasher. Sterilizing the jars before you use them removes any bacteria that could make your puree go bad once you’ve canned it.

steps.headline: Place the lids in simmering water to soften them.
steps.description: Bring a pot of water to a boil, and then turn down the heat so that the water is bubbling gently before putting the lids in. It should take 1-2 minutes for the lids to soften, and will make it easier for the jars to get a good seal. Simmering the lids will also sterilize them. You want at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) of water covering the lids, and to make sure the lids aren’t stacked or overlapping so that they heat evenly.

steps.headline: Put 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of lemon juice in the bottom of each jar.
steps.description: This will prevent botulism and keep your puree fresh. As lemon juice may change the flavor a little, you can use ¼ teaspoon of citric acid instead of lemon juice, if you prefer.

steps.headline: Bring the puree to a simmer.
steps.description: Put the puree in a pot and warm it on the stove at low or medium heat. Stir it occasionally so that the puree doesn't stick to the bottom of the pot. After about 10 minutes, check the temperature of the puree, and take it off the heat when it reaches around 165 °F (74 °C). Using heated puree in the canning process removes any air and gives you a tighter seal.

steps.headline: Poor the heated puree into the jars.
steps.description: Leave 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) of space at between the puree and the top of the jar. This gap is called “headspace” and allows room for the puree to expand as it cools without breaking the seal.

steps.headline: Stir the puree to remove any air bubbles.
steps.description: Getting rid of any bubbles will help stop the puree from expanding after it's sealed. Wipe off any puree that has spilled over the rim of the jar with a paper towel or clean cloth.

steps.headline: Apply the lids to the jars and tighten the screw bands to secure them.
steps.description: The lids will form a seal as the puree cools.

steps.headline: Place the sealed jars into a pot of water and boil for 35-40 minutes.
steps.description: Put a round baking rack in the bottom of the pot before you boil the water. When the water comes to a boil, carefully place the jars on the rack so that they don't touch the bottom of the pot. This stops the puree at the bottom of the jar from getting burnt, which could change the flavor. The water level should come around half way up the jar. You'll hear a popping or pinging sound when the jar has sealed.

steps.headline: Remove jars from the pot and let them to cool.
steps.description: Once cooled, the jars of puree will keep for up to a year in a cool, dark pantry. Once you open the jar, the puree will last for 5-7 days in the fridge.
